headline: Big Tech earnings, Powell remarks, housing data: What to Watch
summary: Market Domination Overtime host Josh Lipton goes over the top stories for investors to watch next week. Plenty of earnings are on deck next week, including from Verizon (VZ) Monday morning, Coca-Cola (KO) and Lockheed Martin (LMT) Tuesday morning, Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) and Tesla (TSLA) Wednesday afternoon, and Intel (INTC) and Deckers (DECK) Thursday afternoon. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell will deliver the opening remarks at a banking conference on Tuesday morning. New home sales data for June will be out on Thursday, with economists expecting an increase to 650,000 from May's 623,000. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime here.

headline: Tesla faces bumpy ride in H2, but real story is autonomy, robots: DB
summary: Investing.com -- Tesla’s second-quarter deliveries topped Deutsche Bank’s forecast thanks to stronger-than-expected results in the US and overseas, but Deutsche Bank analysts remain cautious on volumes and margins for the rest of 2025—even as they double down on the long-term promise of autonomous driving and humanoid robotics as Tesla’s true growth engine.

headline: Business Lookahead: Rate decisions, business activity surveys
summary: STORY: From central bank meetings to reports from some of the "Magnificent Seven," these are the stories to watch in business and finance in the coming week.:: Look Ahead:: Set to pauseThe European Central Bank is set to pause on Thursday after eight consecutive rate cuts halved its policy rate to 2%.It comes as a 30% U.S. tariff threat looms over the euro zone.Policymakers will be reluctant to create the sense that they are reacting to a threat, but they’ll have to reassess their worst case scenario from June, which foresaw a lower tariff level.:: Earnings in earnestMore than one-fifth of S&P 500 companies are expected to report in the coming week.Market heavyweights Alphabet and Tesla are the first of the “Magnificent Seven” to report this period.:: Coca-ColaResults are also due from Coca-Cola, IBM and Phillip Moris International.:: Business timeJuly surveys of business activity across the globe may capture shifts in behavior in both services and manufacturing in response to Trump’s new August 1 tariff deadline.Twenty-two of the world’s 34 largest economies have slowing activity, leaving the services sector to do much of the heavy lifting.In June, services activity in the U.S., euro zone, China and Germany were slower than in December, and well below last June.Among richer nations, only Japan and Britain saw a year-on-year improvement in service-sector activity last month.:: Turkey’s central bankTurkey’s central bank is expected to return to rate cuts on Thursday.That's after the March detention of Istanbul Mayor Ekrem Imamoglu roiled markets, knocked the lira to a record low, saw stocks trading suspended and prompted the central bank to hike overnight rates to 46%.A Reuters poll showed expectations for a 250-basis point cut, with some predicting as much as 350 bps.Central banks in Hungary and Russia also hold rate meetings in the coming week.

raw.headline: Business Lookahead: Rate decisions, business activity surveys
raw.summary: STORY: From central bank meetings to reports from some of the "Magnificent Seven," these are the stories to watch in business and finance in the coming week.:: Look Ahead:: Set to pauseThe European Central Bank is set to pause on Thursday after eight consecutive rate cuts halved its policy rate to 2%.It comes as a 30% U.S. tariff threat looms over the euro zone.Policymakers will be reluctant to create the sense that they are reacting to a threat, but they’ll have to reassess their worst case scenario from June, which foresaw a lower tariff level.:: Earnings in earnestMore than one-fifth of S&P 500 companies are expected to report in the coming week.Market heavyweights Alphabet and Tesla are the first of the “Magnificent Seven” to report this period.:: Coca-ColaResults are also due from Coca-Cola, IBM and Phillip Moris International.:: Business timeJuly surveys of business activity across the globe may capture shifts in behavior in both services and manufacturing in response to Trump’s new August 1 tariff deadline.Twenty-two of the world’s 34 largest economies have slowing activity, leaving the services sector to do much of the heavy lifting.In June, services activity in the U.S., euro zone, China and Germany were slower than in December, and well below last June.Among richer nations, only Japan and Britain saw a year-on-year improvement in service-sector activity last month.:: Turkey’s central bankTurkey’s central bank is expected to return to rate cuts on Thursday.That's after the March detention of Istanbul Mayor Ekrem Imamoglu roiled markets, knocked the lira to a record low, saw stocks trading suspended and prompted the central bank to hike overnight rates to 46%.A Reuters poll showed expectations for a 250-basis point cut, with some predicting as much as 350 bps.Central banks in Hungary and Russia also hold rate meetings in the coming week.

headline: Stock Market Today: Stocks Fall As Google, Tesla Earnings Loom; Netflix Dives On Results (Live Coverage)
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average pared its losses but couldn't get out of negative ground Friday as tariff concerns resurfaced with President Donald Trump reportedly pushing for steeper levies from the European Union.  Decliners on the stock market today included American Express while Google-parent Alphabet managed some gains.  The blue-chip index had stumbled by more than 200 points earlier after the Financial Times reported that Trump wants a minimum tariff of 15% to 20% on EU goods brought into U.S. The report, citing unnamed sources, said a 10% tariff on most items had been part of discussions regarding a framework trade agreement.

raw.headline: Stock Market Today: Stocks Fall As Google, Tesla Earnings Loom; Netflix Dives On Results (Live Coverage)
raw.summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average pared its losses but couldn't get out of negative ground Friday as tariff concerns resurfaced with President Donald Trump reportedly pushing for steeper levies from the European Union.  Decliners on the stock market today included American Express while Google-parent Alphabet managed some gains.  The blue-chip index had stumbled by more than 200 points earlier after the Financial Times reported that Trump wants a minimum tariff of 15% to 20% on EU goods brought into U.S. The report, citing unnamed sources, said a 10% tariff on most items had been part of discussions regarding a framework trade agreement.

headline: Exclusive-Tesla IT exec with no traditional car-sales experience is running sales, sources say
summary: (Reuters) -A relatively little-known information technology executive is running Tesla's sales team as the electric carmaker grapples with a drop in sales, according to people familiar with the matter.  Raj Jegannathan, a senior executive with a wide purview including several IT and data functions, recently took over the sales role, said the people familiar with the matter.  Jegannathan, who has recently grown closer to CEO Elon Musk, has no traditional sales experience, according to two people familiar with the matter and his LinkedIn profile.

headline: A Weak Dollar Has Added Heft to S&P 500 Earnings. A Flip Could Be Coming.
summary: A weakening dollar has provided a solid lift to early second-quarter earnings, but it could be masking softness in domestic demand and potential pressures on profit margins as tariffs increase over the coming months.  The greenback has fallen nearly 9.5% so far this year and is pinned near the lowest levels since 2022 amid a mixture of slowing growth prospects, rising fiscal deficits and worries over the safety of longer term investment in American assets.  Data from Apollo Global suggests companies within the benchmark generate around 41% of their total revenue from outside the U.S., and a weaker dollar increases their value when it comes to financial reporting.

raw.headline: A Weak Dollar Has Added Heft to S&P 500 Earnings. A Flip Could Be Coming.

The greenback has fallen nearly 9.5% so far this year and is pinned near the lowest levels since 2022 amid a mixture of slowing growth prospects, rising fiscal deficits and worries over the safety of longer term investment in American assets.  Data from Apollo Global suggests companies within the benchmark generate around 41% of their total revenue from outside the U.S., and a weaker dollar increases their value when it comes to financial reporting.

headline: Tesla Stock Heads for Weekly Gain. Why This China Graphite Tariff Could Affect EV Prices.
summary: Tesla  stock rose early Friday as investors weighed new import duties on material for electric-vehicle batteries from China.  Shares of the car company led by CEO Elon Musk rose 1.3% to $323.45 in early trading, while the  and  were up 0.3% and 0.1%, respectively.  The Commerce Department on Thursday ruled that China is illegally dumping graphite materials into the U.S. An anti-dumping duty, which is similar to a tariff, of 93.5% was placed on certain graphite imports.

headline: Industrial sector's gains to be tested as earnings ramp up
summary: NEW YORK (Reuters) -The industrial sector has led the way for U.S. equities during a topsy-turvy year on Wall Street, but its strength will be tested as earnings season heats up.  S&P 500 industrials, which include aerospace companies, electrical equipment and machinery makers, transportation firms and building products companies, have gained 15% so far in 2025.  Momentum for the industrials sector and the broader market will be in focus with a heavy upcoming week of second-quarter earnings, which includes reports from more than one-fifth of the S&P 500, led by Alphabet and Tesla, the first of the "Magnificent Seven" megacap tech and growth companies to report.

headline: Should You Buy Tesla Stock While It's Below $330?
summary: Tesla's stock is trading at a high premium.  Elon Musk is still distracted by politics at a time when Tesla needs a committed leader.  Tesla (NASDAQ: TSLA) has been a monster stock for many investors, with shares more than doubling the S&P 500's gains over the past five years.
